results.title: Crete: the island in history. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: The relation of Crete to trade routes and centres of the ancient world is considered. The history of Crete is briefly traced, indicating the various empires which at times have occupied the island. These include: the Macedonian empire, the Roman empire, the Byzantine empire, the Saracens, the Venetians, the Ottoman empire, Greece and the German military occupation.

results.title: Crete: the island and it's people. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Characteristic activities in a small village are shown; grinding of corn, farming, irrigation, hand reaping and threshing, growing of oranges, shearing and spinning wool, pottery making using the wheel, market day activities, ploughing with a primitive plough.

results.title: Crete: an introduction to an island. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Diagrams and models illustrate the geography, topography and brief geological history of the island. Subject-matter covered includes: transport on the island; water supply for irrigation; typical scenery in Western Crete; variations in climatic conditions throughout the island; agricultural pursuits; soil erosion resulting from excessive removal of trees for firewood; declining soil fertility of the land.

results.title: Credits included: a video in red and green
results.brief_description: This experimental documentary exhibits the rise of the sublime architecture of shattered shop signs and bricks in war-torn Beirut, creating poignant juxtapositions of progress, beauty and regress. As the filmmaker drives around the ruins of Beirut he documents, amid the chaos and the ruins, signs of life. Toufic films the inmates of the Fanar Mental Hospital; disabled adult men, living in a decrepit institution - a reflection on the forgotten underclass of any society that is torn asunder by war. He then interviews a Lebanese man who is enraged by the injustices that he sees committed around him, identifying himself as a messenger of the prophet Mohammed and Jesus Christ. Finally Toufic ponders the future - what is the destiny of Lebanese children growing up amid conflict; these children display hope and joy as they play, exhibiting innocence. Jalal Toufic is a writer, film theorist, and video artist. This work, “Credits Included: A Video in Red and Green” addresses issues of being a refugee, of displaced persons, of homelessness and destruction. In English and Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Creatures of the dawn
results.brief_description: Depicts some of Australia’s better known mammals and birds in their natural habitat. Includes koalas, kookaburras, kangaroos, platypus, spiny anteater, giant fruit bats, pelicans and black swans.

results.title: Creatures in clay: ceramic sculpture by Rosemary Wren
results.creator_credit: J M Anderson Films and Films for Potters
results.brief_description: This film about pottery shows in some detail, Rosemary Wren’s technique of building large figures, using T-shaped coils, and making small models by thumbing and pinching.

results.title: Creativity at school
results.brief_description: High school students learn to think creatively in a Technical Activities Centre where they apply what they have learned to model building projects. An experiment in science education at Sevenoaks School in Kent; boys apply the principals learned to creating a variety of models, instruments and machines including wireless controlled model boats and racing cars, an instrument to give blind people signals about their physical environment and a simple computer. The nature of this experiment makes this film an important educational record.

results.title: Creative problem solving: how to get better ideas
results.brief_description: Shows how individuals function with unconscious mental restrictions, and tells how to become free of such restrictions and discover our own creativity, thus increasing the ability to solve problems. Examines several of the common emotional, perceptual, cultural and environmental blocks that limit the quality of out ideas. Looks at problem solving techniques such as ‘brainstorming’ and ‘synectics’, shows how the concepts discussed in the film can be utilised, and explains ways in which management can encourage creativity within an organisation.
